title: How to Make a Soup Without a Recipe

steps.headline: Find a pot large enough for the soup.
steps.description: A two quart (1.89 liter) pot is minimum, but 4-8 quarts (3.7 liters - 7.6 liters) would be best.

steps.headline: Determine what ingredients you have on hand to decide what kind of soup you will make.
steps.description: Basic ingredients include meat, vegetables, grains, legumes, or fruit. Other potential ingredients include spices, herbs, acid (like vinegar or lemon juice), and fat (like butter or cream). Some basic soup styles include savory, sweet, or sour; hot or cold; heavy or light; cream or clear (consommé). Divide your ingredients into those for the stock, and those for the finished soup.

steps.headline: Decide if you will use dry beans or grains.
steps.description: Dry beans require pre-cooking, either by an over-night soak, or a 2 hour soak in water that is first brought to a boil, then turned off and covered. You can speed things up by using canned beans. Grains such as buckwheat or brown rice need up to an hour to cook (see the package for cooking time).

steps.headline: Make Your Stock.
steps.description: For the stock, start with water, and flavor it with vegetables, cooked or raw meat, fresh fish parts, canned stock or dry cubes, or even just plain onions. After your stock is made, you'll have to add new ingredients to make the finished soup, so make sure you don't use everything in the stock.

steps.headline: Finish your Stock.
steps.description: After your stock has simmered for a while (half hour to an hour for vegetables only, 1+ hours for stock with meat); remove all of the stock ingredients and discard them. Filter the stock through a cheesecloth or strainer, if necessary. If you've used meat, and you have the time, cool the stock to separate any extra fat - put the stock in the refrigerator and wait for the fat to rise to the top and solidify, then scoop off with a spoon.

steps.headline: Start your soup: Add dry beans (soaked) and hard grains with the meats, or at the beginning of making a vegetable soup.
Add vegetables in the order of their hardness.
steps.description: For pure vegetable soups, add the vegetables at the beginning of boiling. For meat soups, add the vegetables at least half an hour after beginning to boil the meats. Wash, peel (if desired), and cut vegetables into uniform bite-sized pieces before adding them to the soup

steps.headline: Cook at a simmer until the meat is very tender or until hard vegetables and grains are tender.
steps.description: Remove all meat bones. You may cool the soup now and finish cooking later, or even on the next day. If you do, skim off any hardened meat fat before re-heating it.

steps.headline: Add soft foods at the end.
steps.description: Soft foods such as pasta and risoni don't need a lot of cooking and will disintegrate if they're overcooked. Leave them for the last few minutes of cooking.

steps.headline: If you want a pureed soup (namely, a soup without any lumps), remove any meat bones and use a blender, hand puree tool, or food processor.
steps.description: (Warning: Hot liquids are very unpredictable in blenders. Be sure to start slowly or else the liquid may explode out the top and burn you!) Take small batches of the solid foods and whirl them with a bit of the stock. Return it to the pot or a separate bowl temporarily. Then return all the pureed soup to the pot and keep it warm.

steps.headline: Add cream if you want a creamed soup.
steps.description: Add up to a cup of milk, cream or half-and-half to the soup, and let it become hot. Do not boil it.

steps.headline: Serve with any garnishes you want.

For pure vegetable soups, add the vegetables at the beginning of boiling. For meat soups, add the vegetables at least half an hour after beginning to boil the meats.
